snippet: With salaries and concerns about injuries soaring, N.F.L. teams are increasingly limiting contact during training camps, which were once grueling ordeals under a merciless sun.
abstract: NFL teams are increasingly limiting physical contact during training camps, as salaries and concerns about injuries continue to soar; coaches and owners are weighing risk and cost of preseason injuries, while players are responding to research outlining cumulative, debilitating effects of recurrent head trauma; precautionary changes have left football's training landscape unrecognizable from decade earlier.

byline.contributor: Ben Shpigel and Scott Cacciola contributed reporting.Ben Shpigel and Scott Cacciola contributed reporting.

lead_paragraph: With salaries and concerns about injuries soaring, N.F.L. teams are increasingly limiting contact during training camps, which were once grueling ordeals under a merciless sun.

headline.main: New Rule at N.F.L.’s Camps: No Tackling. It’s Just Practice.
headline.print_headline: New Rule at N.F.L.’s Camps: No Tackling. It’s Just Practice.
